snippet.title: CBA embroiled in laundering scandal
snippet.content:
AUTHORITIES have accused the Commonwealth Bank of a staggering 53,700 contraventions of money laundering regulations. The financial intelligence and regulatory agency it will begin action against the bank - one of the country's largest - over the alleged breaches. Peter Clark, the acting head of the authority, said an investigation into CBA's compliance focused particularly on its (IDMs). As a result, it will allege there were more than 53,000 breaches of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing (AML/CTF) Act. Mr Clark said CBA did not carry out any assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing risk of IDMs before their rollout in 2012. "For a period of three years, CBA did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts," a statement said. "AUSTRAC alleges that the bank failed to report suspiciou`s matters either on time or at all involving transactions totalling over $77 million. "Even after CBA became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ... risk."
Mr Clark said that today's action should send a clear message to all reporting entities about the importance of meeting their obligations. "By failing to have sound AML/CTF systems and controls in place, businesses are at risk of being misused for criminal purposes," Mr Clark said. "AUSTRAC's goal is to have a financial sector that is vigilant and capable of responding, including through innovation, to threats of criminal exploitation." Fairfax Media reported that CBA had acknowledged the proceedings but would not comment further. AUSTRAC's statement of claim in the Federal Court relates to at least four different laundering syndicates, accused of using CBA teller machines, Fairfax said. Originally published as
